awd_titl_txt: Inuit Studies Conference October 2012: Learning From the Top of the World
awd_abstract_narration:
The proposal is to provide funding to the 18th biennial gathering of Arctic scholars known as the Inuit Studies Conference (ISC) for broadening participation of Arctic indigenous people, students and early career scientists in the conference and to support digital media platforms to widen the public audience for the conference.  

The 18th ISC will be addressing the central theme, "Inuit/Arctic/Connections: Learning from the Top of the World," which will be held for the first time in the "Lower '48" at the Smithsonian Institution 24-28 October, 2012. The conference will address the outstanding issue of the Arctic world today, it's rapidly changing climate and the dramatic reduction of sea ice that is transforming a "frozen" world into a seasonally ice-free environment. These physical changes have already had a profound impact on Arctic cultures and residents, on the natural resources that sustain northern peoples, and for the first time directly affect the wider world as a result of new access to formerly frozen lands and waters. The conference will focus on communicating new research on a broad array of northern topics and will raise awareness about these issues in a series of plenary sessions, workshops, symposia, panel discussions, media events, and exhibitions.

An important part of the NSF support will be to expand the traditional format by situating ISC-18 in a contemporary digital environment by developing an extensive website and by broadcasting key sessions and events in streaming media with interactive communication techniques. This proposal seeks funds to ensure participation of young as well as seasoned scholars and to implement a digital communication plan that expands the impact of the conference from attendees to the wider world.

From October 24 to 28, 2012 the Smithsonian Institution in Washington, D.C. hosted the 18th biennial Inuit Studies Conference (ISC) at multiple venues throughout the National Mall. Organised by the Smithsonian Institution’s Arctic Studies Center (ASC) and funded primarily by the National Science Foundation (NSF), the 18th ISC was the largest-ever Inuit Studies meeting including almost 600 Arctic scientists, anthropologists, linguists, archaeologists, and historians, as well as educators, health workers, and government specialists, and Inuit artists, filmmakers, and cultural activists from Canada, Greenland, Alaska, and Russia. The conference featured a concurrent online conference where an audience of over one thousand from 17 countries and 42 states tuned into lectures, plenary talks and interviews with Inuit artists, northern experts and leaders. The overall conference theme—Arctic/Inuit/Connections: Learning from the Top of the World—focused on the acute changes and experiences of Inuit and Native people and ways of life across the Arctic. The eight conference themes included Heritage Museums and the North; Globalization: An Arctic Story; Power, Governance and Politics in the North; The ‘New’ Arctic: Social, Cultural and Climate Change; Inuit Education and Health; Inuit Languages and Literature; Inuit Art, Film and Media: Visual Anthropology of the North; and Perceptions of the Past, A More Inclusive Archaeology.

 

The conference program featured 73 sessions with four to six papers each totally approximately 300 presentations covering the eight conference themes. Presentations were held across several venues on the National Mall such as the S. Dillon Ripley Center; the National Museum of the American Indian; the National Museum of Natural History; and the Woodrow Wilson International Center. A two-part Arctic policy session was held at the Woodrow Wilson International Center and included talks by representatives of the U.S. Department of the Interior, the National Parks Service, and the Inuit Circumpolar Council, as well as by Lt. Governor Mead Treadwell and many others. Sessions covering topics such as Arctic archaeology, Inuit art, literature, education, governance, industrial development, climate change, globalization, and traditional knowledge spanned multiple sessions and days discussing the latest research emerging from this discipline in recent years.

 

Through the support from NSF, a significant number of Inuit and Native Alaskan elders, leaders, scholars and students were able to travel from various Arctic communities to attend the conference in Washington, DC, present their research, share their knowledge and experiences and engage with other researchers and Inuit from across the world. Highlights of the conference program included plenary talks by Lt. Governor Mead Treadwell of Alaska, Mark Serreze of the National Snow and Ice Data Center, Nellie Cournoyea of the Inuvialuit Regional Corporation, and Aron Crowell of the Arctic Studies Center, Alaska Office.

 

In addition to the comprehensive scientific and research paper presentations, the conference featured a comprehensive Inuit arts program.
